bluemodern,"2012-11-11T12:35:23.023Z","Nice Hobbit set at a good value","My local grocery/department store got this set in early (while also having it on sale) so I had to pick it up. The set has 298 pieces including 4 minifigs for a retail price of $30 in the U.S. The set also has dark red leaves (which I think is the first time they have had that element in that color) and some other dark red plates and small slopes. I think this is a good value for the price.

[img]http://i.imgur.com/GLW6C.jpg?2[/img]
The front of the box. It says special preview set on the front.

[img]http://i.imgur.com/DW1H5.jpg?2[/img]
The back of the box.
column2:
[img]http://i.imgur.com/j2vVo.jpg?2[/img]
The minifigs in this set are excellent. The set is divided into 2 numbered bags. In the first bag are the Legolas and Tauriel minifigures. They both look excellent. I got an extra one of her blades/swords as well (for 3 total). The blades are grey with yellow handles and yellow lines in the middle of the blades. I know some people have problems with LEGO having very few female characters (and the ones they have often needing to be saved) so it is great to see a really cool looking female character who appears to be doing the saving in this set.
column3:
[img]http://i.imgur.com/NFehy.jpg?2[/img]
The other two minifigs in this set are Fili and Kili. They both have short legs and look really good as well. They have what I think maybe new hair pieces (which go around a quiver, which they both wear). All 4 of the figures have double sided printing on their heads (one angry face and one normal face).
column4:
[img]http://i.imgur.com/W4nF7.jpg?1[/img]
The first bag contains the Legolas and Tauriel minifigs and the parts for two spiders. When I first saw the set I was a little
column5:
ambivalent about the spiders but after putting them together I think they look kind of cute. They have 2 1x1 round plates for eyes, which are glow-in-the-dark. Their back part is attached by hinges and can move up and down. They are repetitive to build though. Both spiders are exactly the same and all the legs are made the same way, and they have 8 legs each!

The second bag has the trees in them.
[img]http://i.imgur.com/MaYLx.jpg?1[/img]
The first tree is small but it does have an extra bow, a skull and a bone.
column6:
[img]http://i.imgur.com/frVKE.jpg?1[/img]
The second tree is much larger. This tree has a big spiderweb, 2 black spiders, a glow-in-the-dark spider, 2 bags or webs, 2 skulls, a bone, and mushrooms which have printed tops. My set was missing one of the cones for the mushroom top to sit on (but I got an extra mushroom top and reddish brown vine). I hope that is not a problem with other people's sets. This tree has a few play features. The white spider can hide in a little nook at the bottom under the mushrooms and there is a technic pin you can push to make it shoot out on unsuspecting minifigs.
column8:
[img]http://i.imgur.com/8CO50.jpg?2[/img]
There is also a technic pin that holds the top of the tree upright. You can pull it out and the top of the tree falls down so you can rescue the dwarves.
column9:
[img]http://i.imgur.com/mmWtP.jpg?2[/img]
Overall, I think this is a nice set. You get a lot of pieces for the price (particularly for a licensed set). I think the black, dark red and dark reddish brown pieces give the set a nice spooky feel. The minifigures are great and the set has a few play functions. There are also no stickers at all on the set, which is nice.

,TRUE,4,4,4,4,4 Odeinoichus","2013-10-28T19:37:30.767Z","Spiders, Gandalf.","

Set #79001 Escape from Mirkwood Spiders: This is another set I've managed to pick up during the month of Bricktober, paid full price at first than got to price adjust it during a sale, so it was a decent savings.
column2: Let's get on with discussing the elements of the set.&nbsp

column1: Box/Instructions

A lot of LEGO's box designs are always sure to grab your attention on the shelf, and here with The Hobbit Theme there is no exception. Much like with other licensed themes of recent years there is a small box in the corner with the names of all the Mini-Figures included in the set.

The action shot on the front of the box looks great, and I can't wait to see this scene in the finished film in the next few months. The only off-putting aspect of the front of the box is the quickly included Special The Hobbit Trilogy Preview Set announcement. Due to the sudden change in the release of the films LEGO had to quickly modify this and the Barrel Escape sets, the red announcement is slightly too large for the box and covers up part of the image on the front.
The back shows off all the features of the set. As well as the weapons included.

The instructions are not protected by any cardboard, a lot of the 25-35$ range sets seem to have this issue as I've picked up a fair number of them in the past few weeks and have run the gamut from curled to squashed and looking very mangled. It would be nice if LEGO adopted a new policy in regards to the instructions. This is a numbered bag set so the instructions are broken up into two sections for each bag.
They are straightforward to follow and work well, provided you get a copy that hasn't been too rolled up making it hard to keep the book open on the pages you need.
Parts

The parts in this set are all very solid looking, honestly there are a lot of black and rich reddish maroon colored pieces, the build includes some nice red leaf pieces for the tree. You also get some glow in the dark items, a few printed pieces to make mushrooms, and some great looking cloth net/web bags to stick your dwarves in.
You also get a lot of nice weapons and some interesting looking large sloped pieces, not sure on the formal name for them just yet.
Minifigures
This set includes four great looking Mini-Figures, all of which are must own characters from The Hobbit film series. You recieve two members of the Dwarf Company, the young Dwarves Kili and Fili.

Kili has a nice dark brown torso with double-sided printing showing off the costume worn by the character in the film, you can see a nice belt/strap over one shoulder and the barest hint of some kind of special looking undershirt.

He has a bow and quiver and a double-sided head showing a neutral expression and a open mouthed determined warrior look as he prepares to defend himself from the spiders. He and Fili have similar, though not identical hair pieces, long highly detailed sculpted parts that capture the look of the characters from the film. The best part is they are sculpted in such a way that they allow for the quiver to fit in a noticeable groove, a nice touch from LEGO. Kili's is black.

Fili shares the same colouring for the torso, while his short legs are a matching dark brown instead of the black Kili uses. The print is again double-sided with belts and a strap over a well worn fur lined vest or more likely jacket.
His weapons include another quiver and two short swords to fight the spiders and he also has a double-sided head with determined and
column2: smiling expressions. Fili has a nice mustache and beard print on his face that is different from the more stubbly look of his brother. He has a nice matching light brown hair piece.

column1: The differences between the two dwarves hairpieces are actually in the coloring and that's pretty much it, on closer examination I've discovered they are pretty much the same exact piece, just using different plastics.

This set also includes two elves, Legolas Greenleaf, a very familiar character for LotR fans. And officially the first LEGO Female elf as this set was released prior to Council of Elrond and Arwen. Tauriel is her name.

Tauriel features a very nice dark brown and green colored body with a double-sided torso print showing off her armor, this printing carries down to the top of her legs. She also has a double-sided head, actually I'll just say it now, every single Mini-Figure in this set has a double-sided head and torso print.

She has a neutral expression and an angry warrior-in-battle expression, she features some cute freckles on her face also. Like with all elves she uses the same hairpiece first introduced with her companion back during the LotR initial wave. This time it's colored red. She is wielding twin Daggers of Time, at least that's what it was called when introduced in the Prince of Persia Theme of LEGO. (The set includes three, two for Tauriel and an extra in case lost or misplaced.)

Legolas just looks superb, he's dressed in the Mirkwood Elf outfit he'll be wearing in the next Hobbit film and has a nice dark brown torso with pearl gold arm combination. His hair prevents him from wearing a quiver unfortuantely, however the print design looks great. With armor running down from the torso onto the upper legs and visible clasps on the back showing how he wears this armor.
I believe his hair and head are the same as his LotR counterpart, though not owning one yet I can't be 100% sure on that. He has a bow for his weapon and that's pretty much it.
Overall these Mini-Figures are impressively detailed, have a rich earthy tone all around and work well with the set.
The build
There are two bags, the first is for building two identical giant spiders. Not as large as Shelob, these are more than likely some of her children, a much smaller breed.

The second bag builds up a small forest set piece with dark foreboding looking trees, the spider's lair. The spiders are kind of repetitive in the build while the trees are a bit more unique, however still a bit lacking. While they do include a lot of wonderfully dark colored pieces I think the design could have been slightly improved upon.
The completed model

The spiders have a few glow-in-the-dark studs for eyes and balance nicely on the eight legs used in their build. Scalewise they look nice next to the Mini-Figures. The fact that they are both identical does take away slightly from their design, though not by much.
The tips of their legs are a bit sharp even though they are made useing a slightly softer plastic, I'd caution how you handle the builds.

The smaller of the two tree models is pretty uneventful, you have a nice brown vine piece and a place to clip the spare bow included in the set. It's got some remains of previous spider victims as well.

The larger of the two tree models is taller, and includes a few play features. When you pull a technic pin out you can topple the tree to release the dwarves from the two web/net bags that store them when captured by the spiders. Another feature is a small technic pin/1x2 brick combination that when pushed forward sends a glow-in-the-dark spider out from a hidden alcove.
There are two regular black spiders with the set also, one of which sits on a glow-in-the-dark web.
Summary

Overall this is a pretty impressive set with a few minor issues. The main model could use a bit of improvement, perhaps if the tree had featured a few more layers to it so that it came off as a bit larger and imposing, perhaps allowing for one of the larger spider models to sit on it less awkwardly.
The Mini-Figures are all very good and you'll need two of them to complete your Dwarf company, while the others are great for expanding your elven army.

I'm especially impressed by the web/net bags they can hold short legged Mini-Figures pretty snuggly, but long-legged Mini-Figures might sit in there a bit oddly. All the colors chosen for this set are very impressive and highly useful for MOCers. I could care less about the play features though, not every set really needs them and in this case I think it's a bit unfortunate that they feel the need to include them in a set aimed more at older kids/collectors.

",TRUE,4,3,3,3,4

lkb57,"2014-03-17T20:31:24.41Z","No Flies, but a lot of Spiders!","

I was anxious to get my hands on this set for a number of reasons: first, it comes with a ton of parts that are incredibly useful for building forest (specifically autumn) scenes
column2: and second, three of the minifigures&nbsp
column3: (Tauriel, Fili and Kili) are exclusive to this set, and all four of them are fantastic. Despite these great pieces and minifigs, my overall opinion of the set was decidedly neutral: the set doesn&#39
column4: t provide a great deal of playability, mainly because while the spiders are fun to build, there isn&#39
column5: t much for them or the minifigs to play on . . . just too little trees that aren&#39
column6: t large enough to stand on.

column1: Parts

As I mentioned above, the set is littered with great parts. For this reason a lone, you should snap this set up if you see it. The dark red leaves and pale mushrooms were definitely my favorite pieces, but you also get a host of arches and slopes that come in handy for either forest or architecture MOCs.
Minifigures
All of them were awesome. Front and back printing, of course, dual expressions for each of them, and printing on the legs for Tauriel and Legolas. Tauriel'
column2: s&nbsp
column3: daggers are a great addition. In short, both the LOTR collectors and people on the hunt for great caste/Historica related accessories will want all four of these figs.

column1: The build
Quick and simple. The spiders were fun to construct (and they look good alongside Shelob), but other than that this set didn'
column2: t throw out any surprises.

column1: Overall opinion
As stated above, despite it'
column2: s great selection of parts, the set kind of failed to come together in any sort of &quot
column3: awesome-ness&quot
column5: s a bad set, it just isn&#39
column6: t anything special, especially when compared to some of the LOTR sets like Gandalf&#39
column7: s Arrival, which somehow manage to come together as a great piece with fun features, despite the small size.

column1: Regardless, if you'
column2: re an LOTR/Hobbit completionist, or on the hunt for pieces/minifig accessories to flesh out a castle MOC, this set is a must-buy.

Telcontar,"2013-01-16T16:17:13.4Z","Spiders in Mirkwood","

While travelling through
column2: Mirkwood the Dwarves are captured by giant spiders&nbsp
column3: and it's up to their burglar, Bilbo Baggins, to save them.

column1:
Box/Instructions

The box shows a picture of this set with the characters in action.
column2: In the corner is a red box which reads ""Special The Hobbit trilogy preview set!"".&nbsp
column3: This is because of what happened last summer.&nbsp
column4: At first when LEGO got licenses to make Hobbit (and LotR) sets there were going to be only two films.&nbsp
column5: In the summer that was changed to three.&nbsp
column6: Consequently the ending of film one got pushed earlier in the story.&nbsp
column7: That is why we don't see this (or Barrel Escape) in the first film (The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey). LEGO was already too far along in the production process to change drastically so they added these red boxes on fronts of the sets and made them special ""preview"" sets.&nbsp
column8: Anyhow, I'm glad because that means more elves!&nbsp

column1:
Parts

In this set we get part of Mirkwood.
column2: At the time of the Hobbit mirkwood was a very twisted and dangerous place, especially the southern part.&nbsp
column3: Because of that we get lots of dark pieces to convey this feeling in the LEGO set.&nbsp
column4: We do get two new, red foliage pieces which are fantastic.&nbsp
column5: The only disappointment is that there are only two of them.&nbsp
column9: you can see those is in the dark, but when you're in the dark you can't see the rest of the set.&nbsp

column1:
Minifigures

Fili: Fili and his brother Kili are the two youngest members of Thorin Oakenshield's company.
column2: Fili's torso&nbsp
column3: is nicely done&nbsp
column4: and is very accurate to the new film.&nbsp
column6: His head is also very accurate with&nbsp
column8: Like most LotR/Hobbit sets his head is double&nbsp
column10: One face is ""neutral/happy"" while the other is ""angry/fighting"".&nbsp
column11:
His hair, which is a new mold, allows for his quiver to fit on his back.

Kili: Kili is Fili's brother and the two are also Thorin's nephews.
column12: Kili's printing is also very accurate to the movie.&nbsp
column14: his face is double sided, one with ""neutral"" the other with an ""angry/fighting"" expression.&nbsp
column15: Just to keep them straight, Fili is the blond one while Kili&nbsp
column22: Thus, we really don't know too much about her.&nbsp
column23: However, this is what the LEGO Hobbit micro-site says: Tauriel is the head of the Elven Guard of Mirkwood. Her name means ""Daughter of Mirkwood"" and she is exactly that. While beautiful and graceful, she is strong and fiercely dangerous with her daggers, bow and arrow if anyone threatens her realm. As most Elves, she distrusts Dwarves but respects and honors the alliance that has long existed between her people and men. Always guided by her strong sense of justice, she is a beloved leader and a powerful ally to her friends.
column25: Whoever she is her printing is very well done.&nbsp
column26: Her leg and torso printing lines up seamlessly.&nbsp
column27: Her hair mold is like other&nbsp
column28: LEGO elves but this time in a new color.&nbsp
column29: She comes with two daggers too.&nbsp
column30: I believe they're from Prince of Persia sets but I'm not sure.&nbsp
column32:
for elvish knives except for a small dent a little above the hilt.

Legolas: Yes, Legolas.
column33: He wasn't in the Hobbit <em>per se,&nbsp
column34: but his father was Thranduil, king of the Mirkwood
column37: Legolas was around a thousand years old at the time of the Lord of the Rings so it is entirely possible that he could've been&nbsp
column38: there during the events of The Hobbit.&nbsp
column39: He's in an entirely different costume than&nbsp
column41: It looks a lot more like Tauriel's as far as design goes.&nbsp
column42: His head, hair, and bow are the same though.

column1:
The build

The build, like most Hobbit sets, was quite enjoyable.
column2: But building the spiders got a little repetitive.&nbsp
column3: Plus it got a little tiring looking at black and brown pieces for a while.&nbsp
column4:
But even with all this it was still great.

…

column1:
The completed model

When finished it looks suitibly menacing and spooky, very fitting for Mirkwood.
column2: The largest tree has a couple ""play funtions"" too.&nbsp
column3: The main one is in the tree itself.&nbsp
column4: When you pull out a technic axle the tree comes down so the elves can rescue (capture rather) the dwarves from the spiders.&nbsp
column5: You can also fire a glow in the dark spider which also uses an axle piece.&nbsp
column6: I haven't mentioned it yet but the sacks that the dwarves are in are very nice.&nbsp
column7: I've been careful with them this far but I'd imagine that they would be easy to tear.&nbsp
column8: Until then they look very nice.&nbsp
column9: The spiders look like miniature versions of Shelob (they were, of course, her descendants).&nbsp
column10: But because they are smaller they are less pose-able.&nbsp
column11: This set looks great as a display and has fantastic playability.&nbsp
column12: This would be great for pretty much anyone who's not arachnophobic.&nbsp
column14:
The price is good too (at least in the US), especially since it's a licensed set.

…

column1:
Summary

This is a great set.
column2: It captures all the danger and spookiness of Mirkwood and packs in hours of future play.&nbsp
column3: I'm just curious to see how this sequence works out in the movie.&nbsp
column4: In the book it's Bilbo who rescues the dwarves from the spiders not Legolas.&nbsp

column1:
alfred_the_buttler,"2019-06-01T05:49:54.18Z","A great small set ","

It may seem odd I would call a set with nearly 300 bricks small, but due to the fact that it contains 4 separate builds, it comes off feeling like a small set. But that isn&rsquo
column2: t a bad thing, this set has a lot to offer.&nbsp

column1: Minifigures
Like all other LOTR minifigures, the ones in this set are great and highly detailed. Kili and Fili
column2: are near identical, in fact their hair is the same mold just different colors, yet they are so nicely detailed that it&rsquo
column3: s diffi to notice their hair is the same mold. The same is true of Legolas and Tauriel, hair is the same mold but different colors, plus their legs contain identical prints. But fear not, the torso prints are unique and both align perfectly with the legs, resulting in another 2 great minifigures. Getting 4 highly detailed minifigures is great for a set of this size, especially considering that Legolas is one of the few characters to appear in both stories.&nbsp

column1: The Build

So you start with the spiders, which are two identical builds. While it may not appear obvious how they get built when looking at the picture of them, as you complete each step of the build, you will feel like you can predict the next stop. The spiders are well designed but very logical, so don&rsquo
column2: t expect any surprises here. The end result is fantastic, they are very believable spiders, however it would have been nice if they had slightly different color palettes. Just one or two different colored bricks would probably have been enough to make each spider unique.&nbsp

column1: Then you have the two trees. I&rsquo
column2: m not quite sure why they needed to be separate, I think they look nice side by side, but I suppose separating them allows for more room to play. The larger tree is certainly the most interesting of the two. It includes 2 play features. First, and most important, by pulling out a technic axel&nbsp
column3: it allows for the tree to fall down. Of course it works well, but it would have been nice if pushing something on the ground or side of the tree would trigger the action, it would have made it a more realistic play feature. I suppose I could always make a modification to do this.&nbsp

column1: The second play feature is quite silly, you can put a small spider under a rock and push it out. Yes it works well, but it&rsquo
column2: s the same technique used in Lego Juniors sets. So sadly the two play features are a little disappointing, they work well but could have used more engineering.&nbsp

column1: The smaller tree is simply just a smaller tree, no play features. Both trees are nice and have great details (skulls and bones) and use very unique Halloween like colors, but neither tree is a complete tree, at best they are only a quarter of a real tree. I would have much preferred one larger much more complete tree, but I suppose this way gives you the ability to set the scene.
Overall
Despite my complaints I do like this set. Sure it could be improved, but at the same time this set up is well done. I highly recommend picking up this set should you get the chance.
